headline: Good Old-Fashioned Pancakes
description: This easy pancake recipe makes delicious, fluffy homemade pancakes from scratch with basic ingredients you probably already have in your pantry!

video.description: See how to make one of our top 5 most popular recipes!
video.name: Good Old Fashioned Pancakes

name: Good Old-Fashioned Pancakes
recipeIngredient: 0.25 teaspoon salt, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Sift flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt together in a large bowl. Make a well in the center and add milk, melted butter, and egg; mix until smooth.

Heat a lightly oiled griddle or pan over medium-high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake; cook until bubbles form and the edges are dry, about 2 to 3 minutes. Flip and cook until browned on the other side. Repeat with remaining batter.

I made this recipe several times, and I see people being really critical, so here are some pieces of advice: 1- do not mix TOO MUCH, it definitely is not a recipe for a hand or stand mixer. You are going to fold the ingredients gently. The amount of baking powder can create gluten faster and you will have tostinos instead of fluffy pancakes if you mix too much. 2- use all the ingredients at room temperature, otherwise, they will not mix properly 3- add the baking powder when everything is already mixed. The baking powder could be combined with all dried ingredients, but it is risky if you don't do it properly. It is safer to add it when all the other ingredients are mixed. 4- Do not press the pancake against the riddle. Never add vanilla to a pancake recipe, that is a crime. The pancake gods are watching you. Just don't. It feels like what I am saying is too obvious, but sometimes those reviewers need pancake 101. Just follow the recipe and you will get it right. People can't cook or bake and they just want to be hateful on the internet.

The amount of baking powder is so crazy high that every bite tastes bitter! And that's after mixing it thoroughly with the flour. You shouldn't need more than 1 to 1 and a half tsp for this recipe! They were great. Everyone saying cold milk in melted butter is a bad idea or bad advice, you are wrong! Stir it fast when you pour in the cold milk and it makes little pieces of solid butter throughout. That makes the pancakes nice and fluffy and tender when you cook them. The moisture in the cold butter evaporates and puffs up! So the person that said they use oil instead of butter then get thin pancakes: it’s either because you changed the butter out and are missing out on that puffing up action. Or your baking powder is old. or you accidentally used baking soda instead of powder. Added tsp of vanilla otherwise followed recipe

They cooked evenly. For those who ended up with bitter cakes… did you use baking soda instead of baking powder? I used baking powder as stated and had no issue.

These were extremely bland, and the advice to pour cold milk onto hot melted butter is terrible baking advice. We put 1/2 tsp of salt and it could've had more. How this got 18k+ reviews to get to 4.6 stars is completely mind blowing. We added blueberries and that was the only redeeming factor.

This is the pancake recipe my daughter always begs me to make. Like many reviewers, I add vanilla. I also add a bit more milk than is called for to thin them out a bit (don’t worry, they’re still huge and fluffy!). My “secret” ingredient is also adding a splash of chocolate extract. It really makes the vanilla flavor pop! Sometimes we will also add other additions, but this is how I make my standard recipe. I don’t measure my extracts, but if I had to guesstimate, I’d say I use about a teaspoon or a teaspoon and a half of vanilla extract and a half teaspoon or so of chocolate extract. To the people saying they didn’t like the baking powder part: make sure you’re reading the measurement correctly (if you get distracted and lose count of the three teaspoons like I tend to do, just use one tablespoon, it’s the same, and then do a pinch more) and make sure you’re whisking all the dry ingredients together first before mixing in the wet ingredients so you don’t get baking powder clumping together. I just use a fork to sift everything together. Hope this helps!
